facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 402 of 1961 filed by special leave against award of Industrial Tribunal Punjab dated February 11, 1960 in Reference No. 5 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 402 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the award dated February 11, 1960, of the Industrial Tribunal, Punjab, Reference No. 5 of 1959. B. Pai, J. B. Dadachanji, 0. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Venkatarama Aiyar J. on March 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the award of the Industrial Tribunal, Punjab, passed in Reference No. 5 of 1959 on February 11, 1960.

facts.text: Appellant is a Public Limited Company incorporated under Indian Companies Act, 1913, manufactures and sells electric cables and wires, registered office at Calcutta, factory at Jamshedpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Public Limited Company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, and it carries on business in the manufacture and sale of electric cables, wires etc. Its registered office is at Calcutta and its factory is located at Jamshedpur.

facts.text: Before January 1, 1956, appellant sold goods through agents Messrs Gillanders Arbuthnot and Co.

anchor.surface_text: Before January 1, 1956, it had numberbranches and was selling its goods through Messrs Gillanders Arbuthnot and Co., as its agents.

facts.text: B.I.C.C. Ltd. carried on business in sale of cables and wires in India with branches at Bombay, Madras, Calcutta, Delhi, Trivandrum, Ahmedabad, Nagpur, Kanpur, Bangalore and Ambala.

anchor.surface_text: During this period, a companypany incorporated in England and called the British Insulated Callendars Cables Ltd. referred to as the B.I.C.C. Ltd., in these proceedings was carrying on business in the sale of cables and wires in India with branches at Bombay, Madras, Calcutta, Delhi, Trivandrum, Ahmedabad, Nagpur, Kanpur, Bangalore and Ambala.

facts.text: Towards end of 1955, B.I.C.C. Ltd. decided to stop trading in India and close its branches.

anchor.surface_text: Towards the end of 1955, the B.I.C.C. Ltd. decided to stop its trading in India and to close its branches.

facts.text: Appellant took over B.I.C.C. branches and ran them as its own from January 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company then decided to take them over and run them as its own. The workmen in the service of the B.I.C.C. Ltd. were most of them offered reemployment on terms and companyditions companytained in a companymunication dated November 23, 1955, sent by the appellant to them, and they having accepted them the branches began to function as those of the appellant from January 1,. 1956.

facts.text: Workmen of B.I.C.C. offered reemployment by appellant on terms in communication dated November 23, 1955, and accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen in the service of the B.I.C.C. Ltd. were most of them offered reemployment on terms and companyditions companytained in a companymunication dated November 23, 1955, sent by the appellant to them, and they having accepted them the branches began to function as those of the appellant from January 1,. 1956.

facts.text: Ambala branch taken over by appellant, business included execution of B.I.C.C. contracts with Government of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Among the branches thus taken over was the one at Ambala. The business of that branch companysisted, apart from the sale of goods manufactured by the appellant, in the execution of the companytracts of the I.C.C. Ltd., with the Government of Punjab, which it had taken over.

facts.text: Beginning of 1958, contracts nearly completed, appellant considered Ambala branch unremunerative and decided to close it.

anchor.surface_text: These companytracts were about to be companypleted in the beginning of 1958, and as, having regard to the volume of its, own business in that area, the appellant companysidered that the maintenance of a branch at Ambala was unremunerative, it decided to close it.

facts.text: On May 8, 1958, appellant terminated services of all 11 workmen at Ambala branch, paid salaries, wages in lieu of notice, retrenchment compensation, gratuity, provident fund, and wound up the branch.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly on May 8, 1958, it terminated the services of all its workmen at Ambala, numbering 11 in all,paid them their salaries, wages in lieu of numberice, retrenchment companypensation, gratuity, and provident fund, and wound up the branch

facts.text: Appellant claims workmen accepted payments without protest and cooperated in despatch of goods.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, the workmen accepted these amounts without any protest and companyoperated with the management in the despatch of its goods to Delhi and other places.

facts.text: Workmen claim they received amounts under protest.

anchor.surface_text: It is the ease of the workmen that they received the amounts under protest. But numberhing, however, turns on this.

facts.text: On June 5, 1958, six discharged workmen sent representation to management complaining closure unjustified, demanding retrenchment on All India seniority basis and right to employment in other branches.

anchor.surface_text: On June 5, 1958, six of the workmen who had been discharged on May 8, 1958, sent a representation to the management companyplaining that the closure of the branch was unjustified, that as all the branches of the Company formed one unit, the retrenchment should be done according to All India seniority basis and that the workmen had a legal right to get employment in the other branches.

facts.text: Copy of representation sent to Punjab Government.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of this representation was sent to the Punjab Government,

facts.text: Punjab Government issued notification on February 2, 1959 referring dispute to Industrial Tribunal Punjab under s.10 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: which issued a numberification on February 2, 1959, referring the dispute for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal, Punjab, under s.  1  d  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Reference terms: Whether retrenchment of six named workmen justified under s.25G, whether seniority pooled across branches, relief if not.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was in these terms - Whether the retrenchment of the following workmen of Ambala Branch of the Indian Cable Company Ltd., is justified and legal under the provisions of section 25 G of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, and whether the seniority of workmen in all the branches of the companypany was pooled for the purpose of effecting retrenchment? If number, to what relief are the following workmen entitled ? Then follow the names of the six workmen.

facts.text: Tribunal overruled appellant's preliminary objections by order dated August 17, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Tribunal, the appellant raised cer- tain preliminary objections to the maintainability of the referedce. By its order dated August 17, 1959, the Tribunal overruled these objections.

facts.text: Tribunal award dated February 11, 1960 directed appellant to reinstate six workmen with continuity from May 8, 1958 and pay full wages till absorbed.

anchor.surface_text: Then the matter was heard on the merits, and on February 11, 1960, the Tribunal pronounced its award directing the appellant to take back the six workmen in their employment with effect from 8 5-1958 so that there is numberbreak in the companytinuity of service of any of them and to pay them their full wages from 8-5-1958 till the date they are absorbed.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside Tribunal award, answered reference against respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed, the order of the Tribunal is set aside and the reference answered against the respondents.

facts.text: Ambala branch had 11 workmen whose services terminated on May 8, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly on May 8, 1958, it terminated the services of all its workmen at Ambala, numbering 11 in all,paid them their salaries, wages in lieu of numberice, retrenchment companypensation, gratuity, and provident fund, and wound up the branch

facts.text: Six workmen are the respondents in the dispute.

facts.text: Court found Ambala branch is a separate industrial establishment under s.25G.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that each branch is a separate industrial establishment.

issues.text: Whether the retrenchment of the following workmen of Ambala Branch of the Indian Cable Company Ltd., is justified and legal under the provisions of section 25 G of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, and whether the seniority of workmen in all the branches of the company was pooled for the purpose of effecting retrenchment?

anchor.surface_text: is justified and legal under the provisions of section 25 G of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, and whether the seniority of workmen in all the branches of the companypany was pooled for the purpose of effecting retrenchment?

anchor.surface_text: The question as to the competence of the Tribunal to entertain or adjudicate on the reference could shortly be disposed of as it is covered by our decisions in The Atlas Cycle Industries Ltd. v. Their Workmen

arguments.claim: s.25A Explanation not applicable to s.25G; industrial establishment in ordinary sense local

anchor.surface_text: Now what is an industrial establishment ? There is a definition of it given in the Explanation to s. 25 A but that is limited to ss. 25C, 25D and 25E ... guided by such indications as the context might furnish.

arguments.claim: Dispute is industrial as raised by majority of Ambala branch workmen

anchor.surface_text: On this finding it follows that the dispute of the respondents is an industrial dispute as defined in s. 2 k as that has been raised by the majority of the workmen of the Ambala branch

arguments.claim: No relief under s.25G as establishment closed validly and not impugned as mala fide

anchor.surface_text: But as the establishment has been closed and the closure itself is not impugned as bad on the ground that it is colourable and not bona fide, s.25G has no application

holdings.text: The notifications appointing Shri A. N. Gujral as Tribunal under s. 7(3) of the Act and as Presiding Officer under s. 7C are valid, the Punjab Act 8 of 1957 is not unconstitutional, and the notifications extending his tenure till June 4, 1959 are intra vires; the Tribunal was competent.

anchor.surface_text: We have held in our Judgments in The Atlas Cycle Industrial case 1 and Ms Dalmia Dadri Cement case 2 that the notification dated April 28, 1953, appointing Shri A. N. Gujral as Tribunal under s. 7 3 of the Act and the notification dated April 19, 1957, appointing him as the Presiding Officer under s. 7C are valid, that the Punjab Act 8 of 1957 is not, unconstitutional,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly following binding Supreme Court precedents in Atlas Cycle Industries Ltd. v. Their Workmen and Dalmia Dadri Cement Ltd. v. Shri A.N. Gujral.

holdings.text: Explanation to s.25A defining 'industrial establishment' is limited to ss.25C-25E and does not apply to s.25G.

anchor.surface_text: Now what is an industrial establishment ? There is a definition of it given in the Explanation to s. 25 A 2  but that is limited to ss. 25C, 25D and 25E, There being no definition of the expression

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language explicitly limits the definition to specific lay-off provisions, requiring ordinary meaning for s.25G.

holdings.text: The decisive elements for determining if units are one industrial establishment are location and functional integrality (common code for categories of workmen and wage scales).

anchor.surface_text: Several tests were referred to in the course of arguments before us such as, geographical proximity, unity of ownership, management and control, unity of employment ... decisive elements are the location of the establishment and the functional integrality

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balancing multiple tests from precedents like Associated Cement Companies; location and functional integrality (wages, cadre) decisive over unity of management alone.

holdings.text: Each branch of the company is a separate industrial establishment under s.25G.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that each branch is a separate industrial establishment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ambala branch has separate location, different wage scales, no transfers or common cadre, separate accounts; satisfies functional integrality test negatively for unity.

holdings.text: The dispute raised by the six respondents is an industrial dispute under s.2(k) as it was raised by the majority of workmen in the Ambala branch (separate establishment).

anchor.surface_text: On this finding it follows that the dispute of the respondents is an industrial dispute as defined in s. 2 k as that has been raised by the majority of the workmen of the Ambala branch,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Six out of eleven workmen in separate Ambala establishment constitute majority affecting class rights; applies precedent requiring considerable number or union support.

holdings.text: s.25G has no application; retrenchment justified as the entire Ambala establishment was closed validly without challenge to closure as mala fide or colourable.

anchor.surface_text: But as the establishment has been closed and the closure itself is not impugned as bad on the ground that it is colourable and not bona fide, s.25G has no application

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid closure terminates all services equally; no surplusage retrenchment requiring last-in-first-out or pooling; no pooling needed across separate establishments.
